summary: a series of symptoms and consequences caused by the influenza virus are not caused by the direct action of the influenza virus itself but are rather due to the inflammatory injury caused by the excessive activation of the immune response induced by an influenza virus infection. the modest cytokine response contributes to the induction of antiviral and Th1-type immune responses in the body. in 1918, the “Spanish flu” also caused fatal inflammatory damage to the lung tissue. this inflammatory injury is both an important cause of death due to influenza virus infection and a major cause of lung infections caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), sepsis, and aspiration pneumonia. immunosuppressive agents (e.g., glucocorticoids) are often used in clinical practice to inhibit inflammatory cytokine responses, thereby blocking disease progression. IGF1 regulates the expression of inflammatory cytokines in response to PR8 infection. the content of IGF1 in the serum of mice was detected by enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) the content of IGF1 protein in the serum increased significantly on day 5 post-infection of PR8 and decreased on day 9. the results were consistent with the qPCR and Western blot findings. mice in the PR8 + IGF1 group were intranasally inoculated with 30 l influenza virus PR8 (50LD50) from 6 h before the inoculation to day 14 post-infection, the mice were intraperitoneally injected with IGF1 protein (20 g/kg/24 h); and the PR8 + PBS group was injected with PBS (30 l/24 h). the clinical symptoms of the mice were observed daily for 14 days, and changes in the survival rate of the PR8 + PPP group was dramatically increased up to 75% compared with the survival rate of the PR8 + PBS group was only 25%. the first death in the PR8 + IGF1 group was accelerated to day 5 post-infection. all mice have succumbed to the infection by day 8. the lung index of the PR8 + IGF1 group increased significantly from 1.953 0.074 to 2.515 0.121%. the area of lung injury also increased from 0.38 0.042 to 0.78 0.069. the level of inflammatory cell infiltration in the lung tissue of the PR8 + PBS group was greater than that of the PR8 + PBS group. the viral load in the lungs of the PR8 + IGF1 group was significantly increased to nearly two-fold of the PR8 + PBS group. however, the viral load of the PR8 + PPP group and the PR8 + PBS group was similar, indicating that IGF1 responded to influenza infection via the host immune response. the results further confirm that IGF1 induced an inflammatory response following influenza virus infection. a Western blot was used to detect the expression of molecules in key signaling pathways in the lung tissue of PR8-infected mice. each sample was from six mice in a group and was tested for three times. IGF1 expression was upregulated in A549 cells and BALB/c mice infected with PR8, which modulated inflammatory cytokine expression. phosphorylation of IGF1R triggered PI3K/AKT and MAPK signaling pathways to induce inflammation. neutralizing antibodies can prevent the adsorption of the virus via opsonization. Activated Th1 cells release various cytokines (i.e., IFN- and TNF), activate macrophages and NK cells to induce further inflammatory reactions. inhibitor PPP was used to inhibit IGF1R function, thereby disrupting its downstream signaling capacity. the inhibition of IGF1 only affects the immune response but has no significant effect on IAV replication. this is consistent with previously reported effective treatments for influenza-mediated inflammation. p-AKT expression was upregulated in the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway. p-p38 and p-JNK expression were upregulated in the MAPK signaling pathway compared with the PBS group. there was no significant difference in the level of p-JNK expression between the groups infected with influenza virus. the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest.
